abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Support for
            Social Services Project for Guatemala were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was moderate, Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: this Emergency
            Recovery Loan (ERL) provides a means of designing a
            fast-disbursing project with the aim of achieving
            medium-term objectives that the government and the Bank are
            in joint agreement on. This type of loan can also be useful
            in the event of an emergency where the government is trying
            to obtain funding quickly but not have the lead time to
            implement development policy reforms. Project design should
            take into account the country's existing reporting
            systems. It is important to manage the administrative
            burdens that come with ERL (as opposed to development policy
            loans). These burdens include compliance with safeguards and
            the preparation of operational manuals, even though the loan
            did not finance any investments and only reimbursed teacher
            and health worker salaries. The triggering of safeguards in
            particular created substantial work- including environmental
            plans, operational manuals, discussions and follow-up, in
            order to deal with an issue that seemed beyond the scope of
            the project. Such administrative requirements need to be
            carefully considered upfront and explained to the client
            during project preparation.
